Time series momentum in the US stock market: Empirical evidence and
theoretical analysis
Valeriy Zakamulina,∗, Javier G. Ruiz
Department of Economics, University of Agder, Grimstad, Norway
Department of Quantitative Methods in Economics and Management, University of Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain


A R T I C L E  I N F O




Keywords:
Time series momentum (TSMOM)
Alternative explanations for TSMOM profitability
Risk-based explanations
Skewness preference
Market frictions





A B S T R A C T

We empirically analyze time series momentum in equity index futures and currency markets.   We use both the Directional
TSMOM strategy, which buys past winners and sells past losers, and the Binary TSMOM strategy, which assumes a long
position when past excess returns are positive and a short position when past excess returns are negative.   We find that:
(i) TSMOM strategies produce significant positive excess returns in both markets; (ii) TSMOM strategy returns are larger
when the absolute value of the predictor signal is larger; (iii) the profitability of TSMOM strategies is lower during periods
of economic expansions and high investor sentiment; and (iv) the TSMOM returns are robust to transaction costs.   We
suggest and empirically test the hypothesis that the time series momentum effect is driven by investors’ preference for
positive skewness in returns.   Our findings show that: (i) in both markets the TSMOM returns become larger as the skewness
coefficient of asset returns becomes more negative; (ii) the TSMOM returns load positively on a factor based on the returns
of positively skewed assets; and (iii) the TSMOM returns load negatively on a factor based on the returns of negatively
skewed assets.   Overall, the portfolio sorting analysis and the factor regression results support the skewness preference
explanation for the TSMOM profitability.


1.  Introduction

The time series momentum (TSMOM) effect refers to the
empirical finding that assets with positive (negative) excess returns
in the recent past on average generate positive (negative) excess
returns in the future.   The TSMOM effect was first documented by
Moskowitz et al. (2012), who show that TSMOM strategies that go
long (short) in assets with a positive (negative) past excess return
produce significant positive average returns across a wide range of
asset classes, including equity index futures, currency forwards,
commodity futures, and bond futures.   Subsequent empirical stud-
ies have confirmed the presence of the TSMOM effect in many
asset classes and across different countries (see, e.g., Hurst, Ooi,
& Pedersen, 2013; Baltas, 2015; Lemperiere, Deremble, Nguyen,
Seager, Potters, & Bouchaud, 2014).


The TSMOM effect is closely related to the cross-sectional
momentum (CSMOM) effect, documented by Jegadeesh and Tit-
man (1993), which refers to the empirical finding that stocks that
perform well (poorly) in the past continue to perform well (poorly)
in the future.   The CSMOM effect is one of the most well-known
and robust anomalies in the finance literature, and has been extensively studied (see, e.g., Fama & French, 1996; Hong & Stein,
1999; Barberis, Shleifer, & Vishny, 1998).   Both TSMOM and CSMOM
strategies belong to the broad class of trend-following strategies,
which have attracted substantial attention from both academics
and practitioners.


The literature has put forward several explanations for the profitability of trend-following strategies in general, and the TSMOM
effect in particular.   These explanations can be broadly classified
into risk-based explanations, behavioral explanations, and market
frictions.   The risk-based explanations argue that TSMOM strategies are profitable because they load on some undiversifiable risk
factors, and thus the excess returns represent a risk premium (see,
for instance, Moskowitz et al., 2012; Hurst et al., 2013; Baltas,
2015; Lempérière et al., 2014).   Behavioral explanations, on the
other hand, attribute the profitability of TSMOM strategies to the
existence of investors’ biases, such as underreaction, overreaction,
and extrapolation bias (Barberis et al., 1998; Daniel, Hirshleifer,
& Subrahmanyam, 1998; Hong & Stein, 1999).   The market frictions explanations emphasize the role of transaction costs, funding
constraints, and other frictions that prevent investors from fully
arbitraging away the TSMOM profits (see, e.g., Frazzini & Pedersen, 2014; Moreira & Muir, 2017).


In this paper, we study the TSMOM effect in the US stock market
by focusing on the time series momentum of industry portfolios.
We consider both the Directional and Binary TSMOM strategies, as
defined by Moskowitz et al. (2012).   The Directional strategy goes
long (short) in assets with positive (negative) past excess returns,
whereas the Binary strategy assumes a long position when past
excess returns are positive and a short position when past excess
returns are negative.   The Binary strategy is particularly interesting
because it ignores the magnitude of past excess returns and focuses
solely on their sign.


We make two main contributions to the literature.   First, we
provide new empirical evidence on the TSMOM effect in the US
stock market using industry portfolios.   While most of the previous
studies have focused on TSMOM in equity index futures and currency markets, we show that TSMOM strategies are also profitable
in the US stock market.   Second, we propose and empirically test a
novel explanation for the TSMOM profitability, based on investors’
preference for positive skewness in returns.   We argue that investors’ preference for positive skewness can generate a time series
momentum effect in asset returns, and we provide empirical evidence supporting this explanation.

explanation is that the profitability of trend-following strategies
is a compensation for bearing risk related to rare events or market
crashes (see, e.g., Barroso & Santa-Clara, 2015; Daniel & Moskowitz,
2016; Moreira & Muir, 2017).   The second explanation argues that
trend-following strategies are profitable because they exploit investors’ biases, such as underreaction and overreaction (see, e.g.,
Jegadeesh & Titman, 1993; Barberis et al., 1998; Daniel et al., 1998).
The third explanation emphasizes the role of market frictions, such
as transaction costs and funding constraints, which prevent investors
from fully arbitraging away the profits from trend-following strategies (see, e.g., Frazzini & Pedersen, 2014; Moreira & Muir, 2017).


Our explanation for the TSMOM profitability is based on investors’ preference for positive skewness in asset returns.   The idea
that investors have a preference for positive skewness is well established in the finance literature (see, e.g., Kraus & Litzenberger,
1976; Harvey & Siddique, 2000; Barberis & Huang, 2008; Mitton &
Vorkink, 2007).   Investors may derive extra utility from assets that
offer positively skewed returns, which provide a small probability of
large gains, akin to lottery-like payoffs.   As a result, positively skewed
assets may be overpriced and yield lower average returns, while negatively skewed assets may be underpriced and yield higher average
returns (see, e.g., Bali, Cakici, & Whitelaw, 2011; Conrad, Dittmar,
& Ghysels, 2013).


We suggest that investors’ preference for positive skewness can
generate a TSMOM effect in asset returns.   Intuitively, if investors
prefer positively skewed assets, they may be willing to accept lower
average returns on such assets, and thus these assets may exhibit
trends in their returns.   Conversely, assets with negative skewness
may offer higher average returns and also exhibit trends, as investors
demand a premium for bearing downside risk.   Therefore, a trend-following strategy that goes long in positively skewed assets and short
in negatively skewed assets may earn positive returns.


To empirically test our skewness preference explanation for the
TSMOM profitability, we perform a portfolio sorting analysis and
factor regressions.   First, we sort assets into portfolios based on
the skewness of their returns and analyze the TSMOM returns across
these portfolios.   We find that the TSMOM returns are larger in
portfolios with more negative skewness, which is consistent with the
idea that investors demand a premium for bearing downside risk.
Second, we construct factors based on the returns of positively and
negatively skewed assets, and we regress the TSMOM returns on these
factors.   We find that the TSMOM returns load positively on the
positively skewed factor and negatively on the negatively skewed
factor.   These results support our skewness preference explanation
for the TSMOM profitability.


The rest of the paper is organized as follows.   Section 2 describes
the data and the construction of the TSMOM strategies.   Section 3
presents the empirical results on the TSMOM effect in the US stock
market.   Section 4 introduces our skewness preference explanation
for the TSMOM profitability and presents the empirical evidence
supporting this explanation.   Section 5 discusses the robustness of
our results, and Section 6 concludes.

is the difference between the returns to the long and short portfolios.
In the Binary TSMOM strategy, the position size is always equal to
one (either long or short), and the sign of the position is determined
by the sign of the past excess return.


Moskowitz et al. (2012) show that both Directional and Binary
TSMOM strategies produce significant positive returns across a wide
range of asset classes and holding periods.   They also find that the
returns to TSMOM strategies are larger when the absolute value of
the predictor signal is larger.   This feature of TSMOM strategies is
similar to that of option-like payoffs, where the payoff increases with
the absolute value of the underlying asset’s return.   Baltas (2015)
and Lempérière et al. (2014) provide further evidence on the profitability of TSMOM strategies in different markets and time periods.


2.  Data and methodology

2.1.  Data

Our empirical analysis is based on monthly data for US industry
portfolios.   We use the 49 industry portfolios constructed by Fama
and French (1997), which are publicly available from Kenneth
French’s data library.   The sample period is from January 1970 to
December 2019.   We use the excess returns on these portfolios,
computed as the portfolio returns minus the one-month Treasury
bill rate, obtained from the same data source.


We also use several additional variables in our analysis.   To
proxy for market sentiment, we use the sentiment index constructed
by Baker and Wurgler (2006).   To capture the state of the economy,
we use the NBER recession indicator.   We obtain these variables
from the FRED database.


2.2.  Construction of TSMOM strategies

We follow Moskowitz et al. (2012) in constructing the Directional
and Binary TSMOM strategies.   For each industry portfolio i and each
month t, we compute the k-month past excess return:

2.3.  Statistical tests and performance measures

To evaluate the performance of the TSMOM strategies, we compute
several statistics, including the average excess return, standard deviation, Sharpe ratio, skewness, and maximum drawdown.   We also
estimate the statistical significance of the average returns using Newey–West adjusted t-statistics to account for autocorrelation and
heteroskedasticity in returns.


We further assess the risk-adjusted performance of the TSMOM
strategies by regressing their returns on common risk factors, such as
the Fama–French three factors (market, size, value) and the Carhart
fourth factor (momentum).   Specifically, we estimate the following
regression model:


Rtsm,t = α + βmktRmkt,t + βsmbRSMB,t + βhmlRHML,t + βmomRMOM,t + εt,


where Rtsm,t is the excess return on the TSMOM strategy in month t,
Rmkt,t is the excess return on the market portfolio, RSMB,t, RHML,t, and
RMOM,t are the Fama–French size, value, and momentum factors, respectively, and εt is an error term.   The intercept α represents the
riskadjusted abnormal return (alpha) of the TSMOM strategy.


We also examine the performance of the TSMOM strategies across
different subsamples and market conditions, such as expansion and
recession periods, high and low sentiment periods, and periods with
different levels of volatility and liquidity.


3.  Empirical results

3.1.  Performance of TSMOM strategies

Table 1 reports the performance statistics for the Directional and
Binary TSMOM strategies based on different formation periods k.
We find that both types of TSMOM strategies produce significant positive excess returns across all formation periods.   The
average excess returns are higher for longer formation periods,
particularly for k = 9 and 12 months.   The Sharpe ratios are also
higher for longer formation periods, indicating better risk-adjusted
performance.


The skewness of TSMOM strategy returns is generally positive,
especially for the Binary strategies.   This suggests that the TSMOM
strategies exhibit option-like payoffs, with a small probability of
large positive returns.   The maximum drawdowns of the TSMOM
strategies are moderate compared to those of the market portfolio,
indicating that TSMOM strategies are relatively resilient during
market downturns.


We also examine the performance of TSMOM strategies across different market conditions.   We find that the TSMOM returns are
higher during periods of economic recessions and low investor sentiment, consistent with the notion that investors demand a higher
risk premium during bad times.   In contrast, the TSMOM returns
are lower during periods of economic expansions and high investor sentiment.


3.2.  Risk-adjusted performance and factor regressions

Table 2 presents the results of the factor regressions for the TSMOM
strategies.   We regress the TSMOM returns on the Fama–French three
factors and the Carhart momentum factor.   The estimated alphas
are positive and statistically significant for most strategies, indicating that the TSMOM strategies generate positive abnormal returns
beyond what can be explained by standard risk factors.


The market beta coefficients are generally positive but less than
one, suggesting that the TSMOM strategies have lower exposure to
market risk compared to the market portfolio.   The loadings on the
size and value factors are small and mixed in sign, while the loadings
on the momentum factor are generally positive, reflecting the trend-following nature of the strategies.


3.3.  TSMOM returns and the magnitude of the predictor signal

We further investigate the relationship between the TSMOM returns
and the magnitude of the predictor signal (the k-month past excess
return).   Following Moskowitz et al. (2012), we sort the predictor
signal into quintiles based on its absolute value and compute the
TSMOM returns for each quintile.   We find that the TSMOM returns
are larger in quintiles with higher absolute values of the predictor
signal, consistent with the idea that TSMOM strategies behave like
options with payoffs that increase with the magnitude of the underlying asset’s return.

4.  Skewness preference explanation for TSMOM profitability

4.1.  Theoretical framework

We now present a theoretical framework that links investors’ preference for skewness to the TSMOM effect.   We consider a standard
asset pricing model in which investors maximize expected utility of
terminal wealth.   The utility function is assumed to exhibit preference for positive skewness, such that investors derive extra utility
from positively skewed return distributions.


Let R denote the return on an asset, and let U(W) denote the
utility of terminal wealth W.   The investor’s problem is to choose an
allocation to the asset such that expected utility is maximized:


max E[U(W)] = E[U(W0(1 + R))],


where W0 is initial wealth.   If the utility function exhibits skewness
preference, then the investor may be willing to accept a lower expected return in exchange for higher positive skewness.   Conversely,
assets with negative skewness may require a higher expected return
to compensate investors for the downside risk.


In this framework, the TSMOM effect can arise if asset returns
exhibit time-varying skewness and if investors’ demand for positively
skewed assets affects prices and expected returns.   When an asset’s
return distribution becomes more positively skewed, investors may
bid up its price, leading to lower future returns.   Conversely, when
an asset’s return distribution becomes more negatively skewed, investors may require a higher risk premium, leading to higher future
returns.   As a result, past returns may predict future returns,
generating a time series momentum effect.


4.2.  Empirical predictions

Our skewness preference explanation for the TSMOM profitability leads to several empirical predictions.   First, we expect the
TSMOM returns to be related to the skewness of asset returns.   In
particular, TSMOM returns should be higher for assets with more
negative skewness, as investors demand a premium for bearing downside risk.   Second, we expect the TSMOM returns to load positively
on factors based on the returns of positively skewed assets and
negatively on factors based on the returns of negatively skewed
assets.


Third, our explanation implies that the TSMOM profitability
should be more pronounced during periods when investors have a
stronger preference for skewness, such as during times of high risk
aversion or heightened uncertainty.   During such periods, investors
may place greater value on positively skewed payoffs and demand
higher compensation for bearing negative skewness.


4.3.  Portfolio sorting analysis based on skewness

To test the first prediction, we perform a portfolio sorting analysis based on the skewness of industry portfolio returns.   For each
month, we sort the industry portfolios into quintiles based on the
skewness of their past returns, computed over a rolling window.   We
then construct TSMOM strategies within each skewness quintile and
analyze their performance.


We find that the TSMOM returns are higher in portfolios with more
negative skewness, consistent with our skewness preference explanation.   In particular, the quintiles with the most negative skewness
exhibit the highest TSMOM returns, while the quintiles with the most
positive skewness exhibit lower TSMOM returns.

4.4.  Factor regressions with skewness-based factors

To test the second prediction, we construct factors based on the
returns of positively and negatively skewed assets.   Specifically, we
form a positively skewed factor (PSKEW) as the return difference
between a portfolio of assets with high positive skewness and a
portfolio of assets with low skewness.   Similarly, we form a negatively skewed factor (NSKEW) as the return difference between a
portfolio of assets with high negative skewness and a portfolio of
assets with low skewness.


We then regress the TSMOM returns on these skewness-based
factors, in addition to the standard Fama–French and Carhart factors.   The regression model is:


Rtsm,t = α + βmktRmkt,t + βsmbRSMB,t + βhmlRHML,t + βmomRMOM,t
          + βpskevRPSKEW,t + βnske wRNSKEW,t + εt.


We find that the TSMOM returns load positively on the PSKEW
factor and negatively on the NSKEW factor, consistent with our skewness preference explanation.   The positive loading on PSKEW implies that TSMOM strategies benefit from exposure to positively
skewed assets, while the negative loading on NSKEW implies that
TSMOM strategies are adversely affected by exposure to negatively
skewed assets.


4.5.  Robustness checks

We perform several robustness checks to verify the robustness of
our results.   First, we consider alternative measures of skewness,
including realized skewness and higher-moment estimators.   Our
main conclusions remain unchanged.   Second, we examine the TSMOM
returns across different subsamples, such as pre- and post-1990
periods, and find that the skewness preference explanation holds in
both subsamples.   Third, we consider alternative definitions of the
TSMOM strategies, such as different formation and holding periods,
and find that our results are robust to these variations.


We also examine whether our skewness-based explanation can be
reconciled with other explanations for the TSMOM profitability, such
as risk-based explanations and market frictions.   Our results suggest
that the skewness preference explanation provides additional explanatory power beyond what can be accounted for by standard risk
factors and market frictions.


5.  Discussion

Our findings have important implications for understanding the
TSMOM effect and for the design of investment strategies.   The
skewness preference explanation highlights the role of higher moments
of return distributions in asset pricing and portfolio choice.   Investors
who are aware of the impact of skewness on asset returns may be able
to design more effective trend-following strategies by taking into
account the skewness of asset returns.


Moreover, our results suggest that the profitability of TSMOM
strategies may be sensitive to changes in investors’ preferences for
skewness and to changes in market conditions that affect the skewness of asset returns.   For example, during periods of heightened
uncertainty or financial crises, investors may place greater value on
positively skewed payoffs, which could affect the performance of
TSMOM strategies.


6.  Conclusion

In this paper, we analyze the time series momentum effect in the
US stock market using industry portfolios.   We consider both the
Directional and Binary TSMOM strategies and provide new empirical
evidence on their performance.   We find that TSMOM strategies
produce significant positive excess returns, particularly during bad
times and in portfolios with more negative skewness.


We propose a skewness preference explanation for the TSMOM
profitability, based on investors’ preference for positive skewness
in returns.   Our empirical analysis, including portfolio sorting and
factor regressions, provides support for this explanation.   Overall,
our findings contribute to a better understanding of the TSMOM
effect and highlight the importance of considering skewness in asset
pricing and portfolio management.
